title: Configure DND-UCMDB integration
content:
Native SACM is a solution for the entire Service Asset & Configuration Management (SACM) process with instant access to the data and embedded graphical widgets for CI topology representation. For more information on how to prepare/deploy Native SACM, see prepare and deploy Native SACM.

A DND resource provider is a lightweight representation of an external resource management platform or external integration points, such as a vCenter server or Amazon's AWS. DND uses instances of resource providers to provision, retire, or operate a resource within these environments. For more information on resource providers, see Providers.

For Cloud Management, if you have deployed the Design and Deploy capability and wish to leverage the advantages of Native SACM for your Cloud Services, you must configure a Deployment Resource Provider for UCMDB, which allows for the integration between DND and UCMDB.

You can enable Native SACM in the following two modes:

  • Classic mode: Service Management connecting with classic UD/UCMDB. For more information on how to install classic UD/UCMDB, see Install UD/UCMDB for Native SACM. 
  • Multi deployment mode: Both Service Management and UD/UCMDB are containerized and deployed on OMT. The containerized UD/UCMDB includes containerized UD, but you need to use external UD for the integration. For more information on how to install UD/UCMDB in Helm, see Install containerized UD/UCMDB.

Configure secure connections between UCMDB Gateway and DND

Perform the following steps to set up a secure connection between DND and UCMDB Gateway. The system administrator should perform these steps.

To import the UCMDB Gateway CA certificate, perform the following steps:

  1. Get the root CA certificate of UCMDB Gateway.
  2. Set the permission for the CA certificate file.
  3. Copy the CA certificate file to the NFS server. 
  4. Restart the pods.

Get the root CA certificate of UCMDB Gateway

First, use one of the following methods to get the root CA certificate.

A certificate chain must contain the root CA and all the intermediate CAs. You must concatenate all the CAs into a single file.

From the browser:

  1. Log in to UCMDB Gateway (https://<UCMDB_HOSTNAME>:<UCMDB_PORT>/cms) from the browser. As an example, the following are steps for Chrome. 
  2. Click the lock icon before the URL on the address bar.
  3. Click Certificate.
  4. On the Certification Path tab, select the site root certificate (the topmost one), and then click View Certificate. If this tab shows only one certificate, the View Certificate option isn't available and you need to directly go to the next step.
  5. On the Details tab, click Copy to File.
  6. In the Certificate Export Wizard, click Next.  
  7. Select the Base-64 encoded X.509 (.CER) format, and click Next.
  8. Follow the rest of the instructions and export the certificate.
  9. Rename the .CER file to .crt file (<UCMDB_Gateway_CA_Certificate>.crt).

Using a command line:

  1. Run the following commands to get the certificate details 
    openssl s_client -connect cmsdemo01.mycompany.net:9443 -showcerts
  2. The output of the command will display the certificates. 
  3. Look for the certificate that has the same s:/CN and i:/CN values.
  4. Copy the last certificate (from -----BEGIN CERTIFICATE----- to -----END CERTIFICATE-----) from the command line output, and then save it as <UCMDB_Gateway_CA_Certificate>.crt. 

Set the permission for the certificate file

Run the following command to set the permissions for the certificate file:

chown <SYSTEM_USER_ID>:<SYSTEM_GROUP_ID> <UCMDB_Gateway_CA_Certificate>.crt

Replace <SYSTEM_USER_ID> and <SYSTEM_GROUP_ID> with the SYSTEM_USER_ID and SYSTEM_GROUP_ID values configured during the suite installation. They're the user ID and group ID of an operating system user used to run the process in the container. For example:

chown 1999:1999 <UCMDB_Gateway_CA_Certificate>.crt

Copy the certificate file to the NFS server

For steps on how to copy the certificate file to the NFS server on a Helm deployment, refer to Import CA certificate into the Suite.

Restart pods

  1. Restart the DND pod by running the following commands: 
    kubectl scale deployment itom-dnd-deploy-controller -n <namespace> --replicas=0
kubectl scale deployment itom-dnd-deploy-controller -n <namespace> --replicas=1
  2. Restart xruntime-platform pods by running the following commands: 
    kubectl scale deployment itom-xruntime-platform -n <namespace> --replicas=0
kubectl scale deployment itom-xruntime-platform -n <namespace> --replicas=3
kubectl scale deployment itom-xruntime-platform-offline -n <namespace> --replicas=0
kubectl scale deployment itom-xruntime-platform-offline -n <namespace> --replicas=1
  3. Restart the cmp-config-controller pod by running the following commands: 
    kubectl scale deployment itom-cmp-config-controller -n <namespace> --replicas=0
kubectl scale deployment itom-cmp-config-controller -n <namespace> --replicas=1

Configure UCMDB Provider

  1. Collect the following details from the Suite Administrator.
    Item Description
    UCMDB Gateway service

    The URL of the UCMDB Gateway server in the following format: http(s)://<UCMDB_Gateway_FQDN>:<UCMDB_Gateway_Port>/cms-gateway.

    For example: https://cmsdemo01.mycompany.net:9443/cms-gateway.

    For classic UD/UCMDB, see Install UD/UCMDB for Native SACM for the UCMDB Gateway URL.

    For containerized UD/UCMDB (multi deployment mode), the UCMDB Gateway service is set up within UD/UCMDB. See the containerized UD/UCMDB installation documentation for the UCMDB Gateway URL.
    UCMDB username

    UD/UCMDB login user who can access the UD/UCMDB database.

    It's recommended that you create a unique account such as dnd_integration in UCMDB. Assign the SuperAdmin role to this account so that the updates made to CIs in UCMDB will be clearly indicated as being made by DND. For more information on how to create integration users in UCMDB, see User permission workflow.
    UCMDB password Password for the UD/UCMDB login user.
    UCMDB customer ID Customer ID on the UCMDB side. To get the value for Customer ID, log in to the Suite Administration portal, select a tenant ID and go to Application Settings > Native SACM settings. Customer ID is the value available in the field UCMDB customer ID. 
  2. Navigate to Administration > Providers > Deployment Resource Providers
  3. Choose the UCMDB from the provider list on the left. If there is an existing UCMDB  resource provider enabled, edit the resource provider for the UCMDB Gateway details as given in step 5.
  4. If the resource provider isn't available, click on the gear icon and select Create Resource Provider.
  5. Fill in the following fields:
    Field Description
    Display Name Enter a descriptive name.
    Description Optionally give it a description.
    Service Access Point
    Server name
    Port

    This is the external UCMDB Gateway endpoint. Example: https://cmsdemo01.mycompany.net:9443/cms-gateway.

    This is the UCMDB Gateway service as given in step 1.
    User ID The UCMDB username given in step 1.
    Password The UCMDB password given in step 1.
    Select Enabled.
  6. Select Create/Save.
  7. Update the following Resource Provider Properties
    1. Navigate to Administration > Providers > Deployment Resource Providers.

    2. Choose OpenText UCMDB from the providers' list on the left. Select the configured UCMDB resource provider.

    3. Click the Properties Tab.
    4. Update the UCMDB Customer ID property with the UCMDB Customer ID that's configured for the tenant. Click Create at the upper right corner. Fill in the following details and save the property.
      • Type : String
      • Name: cmsCustomerId
      • Display Name: UCMDB Customer ID
      • Property Value: UCMDB customer ID (example: 998119331)

Apply the UCMDB license

You need to apply a UCMDB license from the JMX Console to complete the integration. For more information on how to apply a license, see Manage UCMDB licenses using the JMX Console.
